) This IRM section provides information and guidance for working cases from Tax Exempt & Government Entities, (TE/GE). (
) Purpose: The purpose of this IRM section is to provide guidance to Appeals Technical Employees (ATEs) working cases from TE/GE. (
) Audience: The primary users of the IRM section are ATEs working Appeals TE/GE cases. (
) Policy Owner: The Appeals Policy Owner for this IRM section is the Case Operations and Support. (
) Program Owner: The Appeals Program Owner of this IRM section is Policy. (
) Primary Stakeholders: Appeals Processing and Support (APS), Counsel, TE/GE are the primary stakeholders for this IRM section. (

) This IRM section provides information and guidance for working: a. Employee Plans (EP) cases. b. Exempt Organizations (EO) cases. c. Government Entities (GE) cases that include Tax Exempt Bonds (TEB), Indian Tribal Governments (ITG), and Federal, State and Local / ment Tax Area, EO Examination (FSL/ET). (

) If a case, already under the jurisdiction of Appeals, was issued a TAM regarding plan qualiﬁcation and status prior to the case coming to Appeals the Appeals proposed disposition is contrary to the TAM, the ATE will submit proposed disposition of the issue contrary to the TAM as a request for a new TAM. ) On cases from the ﬁeld with TAM’s regarding issues other than plan tion and status, Appeals will follow conclusions that are favorable to the taxpayer and for TAMs that are unfavorable to the taxpayer, Appeals may settle the issues. If a full concession of an issue is recommended by Appeals and is contrary to the TAM’s position, without offsetting consideration, the will submit a proposed disposition of the issue contrary to the TAM as a request for a new TAM. However, if the facts upon which the TAM is based different, a new TAM will not be required. See Rev. Proc.
(updated annually). (
) ATEs may request a TAM where a lack of uniformity exists or the issue is unusual or complex. Appeals will follow the TAM issued to Appeals. (
) A taxpayer may also request that a case under Appeals jurisdiction be for a TAM. The request may be denied, however, if Appeals determines that TAM is not warranted. (
) Requests for discretionary relief under IRC
(b) from the retroactive effect of an adverse action are not mandatory TAMS. (

e. Excess beneﬁt transactions involving a series of contractual payments under a single arrangement will be treated as one excess beneﬁt transac- tion for each year the series continues. The Occurrence Date for each excess beneﬁt transaction in the series will be the earlier of;
) the last payment in the series within the disqualiﬁed person’s tax year, or
) the last day of the disqualiﬁed person’s tax year. Example: On January
, an applicable tax exempt organization leases a car for Mr. X, a disqualiﬁed person. The lease continues through December
, and Mr. X is not required to account for the use of the car (i.e. mileage log). The organization is on a ﬁscal year ending June

tax year and Mr. X is on a calendar tax year. The monthly lease payments are a series of payments under a single arrangement and are deemed to be paid to Mr. X on the last day of Mr. X’s tax year (i.e. Occurrence Date of December
). The occurrence date falls in the organization’s ﬁscal year ending June
(EO’s Taxable Year).

) the last payment in the series within the disqualiﬁed person’s tax year, or

On January

tax year and Mr. X is on a calendar tax year. The monthly lease payments are a series of payments under a single arrangement and are deemed to be paid to Mr. X on the last day of Mr. X’s tax year (i.e. Occurrence Date of December
). The occurrence date falls in the organization’s ﬁscal year ending June
(EO’s Taxable Year).

) The TEB program is responsible for oversight, compliance and education related to arrangements that involve debt instruments or obligations of (TEB) their political subdivisions and other entities entitled to issue tax exempt instruments under IRC
and certain tax credit bonds. These instruments may include: a. Tax Exempt Bonds b. Tax Credit Bonds c. Direct Pay Bonds (
) There are two types of Tax Exempt bonds under IRC

: a. Governmental Bonds – All of the bond proceeds used by the issuer for own purposes. b. Qualiﬁed Private Activity Bonds – Bond proceeds loaned to for-proﬁt or nonproﬁt entity to fund the borrower’s project. IRC

permits state and local governments to issue bonds, the interest which is excluded from the gross income of the bondholder. In order to for this beneﬁt, the bonds must comply with the provisions of IRC
, sections of the Code, and the accompanying regulations. (

) In Tax Credit Bonds, the interest is in the form of a tax credit rather than an interest payment to the bondholder. It is possible that a tax credit bond continue to be a qualiﬁed bond while a controversy exists over the amount the credit available. (
) Direct Pay Bonds issued under IRC

are a type of tax credit bond but issuer receives a payment from the IRS to cover a certain percentage of the interest paid by the issuer of the bonds. The interest paid on Direct Pay is taxable to the recipient. (
) TEB cases in Appeals may involve the following issues: a. Qualiﬁcation of private activity bond. b. Arbitrage transactions. c. Violations of IRC
, IRC
, or IRC
d. Revocation of the IRC
) status of an organization that is the borrower of tax exempt bond proceeds. e. Penalty waivers for late ﬁling of Form
series. f. Computation of rebate. g. Disallowance of a claim for recovery of a rebate. h. Qualiﬁcation of a qualiﬁed tax credit bond. i. Claims regarding credits allowable under IRC
Note: All of the above, except for f, g, h, and i will result in a determination that interest on the bonds is taxable. (

) A tax exempt bond can only be issued by a qualiﬁed issuer. The term includes any state, any political subdivision of a state, and any corporation described in IRC
(d) . It also includes any “on-behalf-of” issuer described Rev. Rul.
C.B.
, and any constituted authority described in Rev. Rul.
C.B.

, if the on-behalf-of issuer or constituted authority has been designated by a state or political subdivision to issue the prospective obligations. The term “issuer” does not include a conduit of the proceeds of the prospective obligations. (

) The proceeds of the bond issue can be used for the issuer’s own purposes can be loaned to another party which is referred to as the “conduit borrower”. The actual owner of the bond (the party which receives the interest is the “bondholder”, also called the “beneﬁcial owner of the bonds”. There are several other parties to the transaction, such as the underwriter, ﬁnancial advisor, bond Counsel, and trustee who will not normally be involved in the examination process. (
) During Appeals consideration, the ATE may work with an employee of the issuer (e.g., the ﬁnance director or an in-house attorney), the issuer’s autho- rized representative named on Form
, an employee of the conduit borrower, and/or the conduit borrower’s authorized representative named on Form

Frequently, if a conduit borrower is involved, the issuer will delegate the handling of the examination and related appeal entirely to the conduit borrower and/or the borrower’s authorized representative. If this happens, it is imperative that the issuer be kept abreast of the status and progress of the case while in Appeals. See IRM
, Disclosure Concerns in TEB Cases. (

) In order to expeditiously conduct an examination (including any related istrative appeal) of a tax exempt bond issue, the issuer is treated as the taxpayer on behalf of the unidentiﬁed bondholders. While bondholders may ultimately be liable for federal taxes upon the completion of the examination and administrative appeal, disputes regarding the tax status of a bond issue are generally resolved at the issuer level by working directly with the bond issuer and/or conduit borrower to the transaction. (

) The bond examination is not an examination of the bond issuer, but of the municipal ﬁnancing arrangement, and the issuer’s records are only reviewed the extent they are relevant to the examination of the transaction. (

) A bondholder is treated as the taxpayer when a preliminary determination been made to pursue a speciﬁc bondholder for assessment and collection of federal taxes. Thus, bondholders should be treated as taxpayers when all three of the following events occur: a. The bondholders are speciﬁcally identiﬁed by name; b. The examination of the issuer has already identiﬁed any speciﬁc issues that would affect the individual bondholder’s liability; and c. A preliminary determination has been made to pursue those issues Note: If TEB determines that the interest on the bonds is taxable and proposes a tax liability on any identiﬁed bondholder’s tax return, it is possible that a bondholder’s unagreed tax liability could accompany the Form
ﬁle to Appeals.

A preliminary determination has been made to pursue those issues further. Note: If TEB determines that the interest on the bonds is taxable and proposes a tax liability on any identiﬁed bondholder’s tax return, it is possible that a bondholder’s unagreed tax liability could accompany the Form
ﬁle to Appeals.
